III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Personal possessions; money; clothing; storage space
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4125
Section (1) A licensee shall have a written policy that designates all of the
Description following:
(c) The method for ensuring that each resident has sufficient
clean, properly fitting, seasonal clothing.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A does not have necessary clothing for winter, no coat,
boots, gloves or a hat. There is only one minor at the facility with
the appropriate winter clothing.
Investigation Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the school on
12/3/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker Youth A
reported not having a winter coat yet and it is because Supervisor
1 keeps telling Youth A that Supervisor will buy a new jacket but
has yet to do so. Youth A also reported of the five youth in the
program, only one of the youths has a jacket for winter. Youth A
reported not having gloves nor boots for winter. Youth A also
reported having gloves and boots, but these items are not for
winter because the boots are for “style not winter”. Youth A
reported having to ask for shoes and being told Youth A already
had shoes. Youth A also reported the shoes were high heels and
Youth A wanted another type of shoe. Youth A reported staff put
off things Youth A wants but generally obtains the items Youth A
needs.
Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
12/3/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported
not being aware of any of the youth including Youth A being
without proper clothing and Youth A has never brought up the
issue to Administrator. Administrator reported all the youth are
provided the appropriate clothing especially when requested by
the youth. Administrator also reported not believing the clothing
inventory is completed each time an item is purchased for the
youth.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
12/3/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported
never being approached by Youth A requesting a jacket and
believes Youth A has a jacket at this time. She also reported none
of the staff have brought up the issue of Youth A needing a jacket
because Youth A was without a jacket. She reported doing
2

seasonal shopping for the youth and making sure each youth has
appropriate clothing for the season. She also reported the facility
has a “care closet” and if a youth needs a jacket, one will be
provided upon request. A generic conversation is always
completed with the youth about their physical needs and a winter
clothing inventory has just been completed. She does fall
shopping in September and coats and jackets shopping in
December. She reported being unaware if an update to the
clothing inventory is completed each time.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
12/3/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported
the facility has provided weather clothing and various items to
wear.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
12/3/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported
the facility has provided weather clothing and various items to
wear.
Youth D was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
12/3/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported
the facility has provided weather clothing and various items to
wear.
Youth E was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
12/3/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported
the facility has provided weather clothing and various items to
wear.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
12/17/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Regarding a
jacket, Staff 1 reported taking Youth A to school on the days Staff
1 works. Staff 1 also reported Youth A was asked about a jacket
and Youth A informed Staff 1 that Youth A doesn’t need a jacket
only a hoodie. Youth A never mentioned to Staff 1 that Youth A
needed a jacket.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
12/17/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Regarding the
allegations of a lack of winter clothing, Staff 2 reported Youth A
doesn’t have a jacket and has refused to go to the store and get a
jacket multiple times. Several efforts have been made to assist
and get Youth A, a jacket, but Youth A continues to refuse. Staff 2
also reported Youth A wants to wear a hoodie rather than a jacket
and is constantly reminded to wear a jacket as the weather gets
colder.
3

Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
12/17/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Regarding a
winter jacket for Youth A, Staff 3 reported not remembering seeing
Youth A in a jacket, but Youth A generally will wear a hoodie or t-
shirt when going to school. He also reported never being asked by
Youth A for a jacket.
Staff 4 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
12/17/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported
Youth A has a winter jacket and a new winter jacket was just
ordered for Youth A because Youth A was refusing to wear the
first jacket. She also reported Youth A has gloves, hat, and boots
for winter but refuses to wear these items at times. She reported
all the youth in the program have winter clothing.
Documents Reviewed:
• DHHS-3377 Clothing Inventory Checklist for Youth A
dated 10/2/24. This document outlines the clothing and
other items Youth A entered care at the facility with. There
is documented an ample supply of clothing (includes items
just purchased) for Youth A. Also attached to this
document are receipts for additional items bought for Youth
A by the facility, which include boots and other clothing
items.
• D.A. Blodgett ST. John’s Home Personnel Procedures –
House Supervisor Procedures. This document outlines
the duties of the house supervisor, and this includes the
completing of a clothing inventory within 24 hours of a
youth’s placement and clothing shopping within 72 hours of
placement. The house supervisor is also to complete a
clothing inventory and clothing shopping quarterly for all
youth in the program. Finally, they are required to ensure
clothing inventories are completed quarterly.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as evidence by interviews with
staff and written documentation. Evidence of appropriate clothing
being provided to Youth A and the other youth in the program is
supported through interviews and written documentation.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Health services; policies and procedures.
Title
4

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and behavioral
health care.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff have not taken youth to ER even though Youth is
experiencing back pain.
Investigation Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the school on
12/3/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth A
reported two weeks ago hurting Youth A’s back after getting into a
fight with Youth B. Youth A also reported being taken to the
Emergency Room for an examination and being told by the
Emergency Room staff that Youth A should return to the
Emergency Room if feeling pain in the next few weeks. Youth A
reported having a doctor’s appointment this week but needed to
go to the Emergency Room over the past week for back pain.
Youth A also reported falling over the past couple of weeks and
staff would not help Youth A up, telling Youth A to get up even
with Youth A’s reported back issues. Staff would not even help
Youth A get up from a chair. Youth A also reported the facility
purchased Youth A a back brace, but the back brace is for
“skinny” people and doesn’t fit. Youth A reported the last Sunday,
Youth A called the Emergency Room because Youth A’s back
pain was severe all over Youth A’s back and the pain moved to
the back of Youth A’s head causing Youth A to have blurred
vision. Youth A reported Staff 2, Staff 3 and Staff 4 informed
Youth A they were not going to take Youth A to the hospital
because the pain was not that bad, and Youth A has a doctor’s
appointment in a couple of days.
Youth A reported disliking this placement in general but also
because staff (Supervisor 1, Staff 2, Staff 3, and Staff 4) are not
nice at times (no specific incident was able to be provided) and
don’t allow Youth A to get food from the refrigerator/pantry when
Youth A wants food and only allows Youth A, a healthy snack.
Youth A also reported these staff (Supervisor, Staff 2, Staff 3,
Staff 4) don’t do anything they should be doing but was unable to
give a specific example. Youth A reported not feeling safe at the
facility. Youth A also reported this fear is based on three of the
four other youth that dislike Youth A. Youth A reported attending
individual and group therapy but avoids the group therapy
because of the other youth disliking Youth A.
School Counselor was interviewed face-to-face at the school
on 12/3/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She
5

reported the only time speaking with Youth A occurred after Youth
A was upset over a fight with another youth (unidentified) at the
placement. She also reported Youth A is not presenting with
behavior issues but is on a safety plan for suicidal ideations. She
did not report any concerns about Youth A’s back.
Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
12/3/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Administrator
reported the incident involving Youth A’s back was placed into
MiSACWIS, and a copy will be provided. She also reported Youth
A has a history of wanting to go to the hospital often especially
when emotionally dysregulated. Administrator reported a belief
that Youth A was not told to return to the Emergency Room but
was to wait until Youth A’s doctors’ appointment tomorrow.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
12/3/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Supervisor
reported not working when Youth A first hurt Youth A’s back. She
also reported Youth A has said Youth A’s back was in pain and
Supervisor purchased a back brace for Youth A. Youth A did
mention the brace was too small and Supervisor was going to
check with the doctor at Youth A’s appointment about another
brace. Supervisor reported helping Youth A anytime Youth A was
observed to be struggling with back pain. She also reported never
observing staff not helping Youth A when Youth A was struggling
with Youth A’s back.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
12/17/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported
the process of providing medical care for Youth A involved giving
pain medication and evaluating any requests by Youth A. Staff are
to call the on-call supervisor for more information and direction.
Staff are also to call the on-call nurse for direction and generally
the on-call nurse will inform staff to take the youth to the
emergency room if unsure of the level of the injury. Staff 1 also
reported Youth A has complained of back pain multiple times and
he has provided the options of a back brace, ice, and/or pain
medication every time. Staff 1 reported helping Youth A when
Youth A sought help in standing from a chair at times and other
times will tell Youth A to take a minute to rest before trying to get
up. Staff 1 also reported not helping when he believes Youth A
has just been walking or running without showing signs of pain
and then asks for help. He bases his assessment on Youth A
showing pain prior before asking for assistance, Staff 2 reported
(this was confirmed by a review of the work scheduled) that Staff 2
was not working at the time Youth A called EMS.
Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
12/17/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported
being present during the allegations of Youth A calling Emergency
6

Medical Services (EMS). He also reported not remembering Youth
A asking for medical care during the shift and was working on
trying to deescalate Youth A following an argument Youth A had
with a peer (unable to recall which peer). Youth A was refusing to
deescalate and Staff 3 believes this may have been around the
time Youth A called EMS.
Video Reviewed:
• Video Review of Youth A the day Youth A called
Emergency Medical Services. This occurred around
7:30 pm. Youth A is observed in the milieu and screaming
at Staff 2. Youth A walked back and forth down the hallway
yelling about Youth A’s candy and the acrylic taste. Youth A
is never heard asking staff to call for Emergency Medical
Services nor is Youth A observed using the phone.
Documents Reviewed:
• Corewell Health Grand Rapids Hospitals Emergency –
Helen Devos Children’s dated 11/10/24 for Youth A. The
chief compliant is documented as “assault and back pain”.
The documented diagnosis is listed as “alleged assault and
lumbar back pain”. Discharge was made following the
medical discharge, which was documented as, Youth A
appears well with vital stable signs. An X-ray on Youth A’s
lower back was conducted, and no evidence of fracture,
dislocation, or destructive processes were found. There
was no concern of a head injury or dislocations. Youth A
was agreeable for discharge. It is documented that Youth A
should follow up with Physician 1 as needed.
• Corewell Health Grand Rapids Hospitals Emergency –
Helen Devos Children’s dated 11/30/24 for Youth A. The
chief compliant is documented as “neck injury and back
injury”. The documented diagnosis is identified as “low back
pain without sciatica, unspecified back pain laterality,
unspecified chronicity”. Discharge was made following the
medical discharge, which was documented as, diffusely
tender to palpation over entirely of back without an
abnormal gait. Youth A denied worsening/additional
symptoms from the initial injury on 11/10/24. It is
documented that Youth A should attend the scheduled
follow up appointment with the PCP scheduled next week.
• Office visit note for Youth A on 12/4/24 as seen by
Physician 1. The reason for this visit is documented as a
rash and back pain. The physical examination documented
indicates Youth A is able to toe walk, heel walk and fully
demonstrate the stretches Youth A does daily in the
7

morning. The recommendation for Youth A is to continue
with daily stretching. Attend scheduled physical therapy
appointment on 12/9/24 and use Vaseline for dry skin relief.
Youth A should consider hydrocortisone cream if symptoms
persist.
• D.A. Blodgett ST. John’s Safety Plan for Youth A dated
5/29/24 and updated 10/2/24. The concerns being
presented and the reason for this safety plan involve Youth
A’s history of suicidal ideation and self-harming behaviors.
Youth A’s strengths are listed as being polite and willing to
share about Youth A’s life. Youth A enjoys self-expression,
swinging, baking and listening to music. The action plan is
documented as; daily check-ins by staff to gauge Youth A’s
mental state. Staff are to document any concerns on the
Behavior Observation Report (BOR). Youth A is to continue
to meet with a master’s level clinician to discuss Youth A’s
current mental state. Youth A is to meet with the facility’s
psychiatrist to discuss concerns and medication needs. If
staff notice any of the symptoms of warning signs, staff are
to check in with Youth A. Staff are to check in with Youth A
if Youth A is alone in Youth A’s room and encourage Youth
A engage in an activity. If it is reported Youth A has had a
bad day staff need to check in with Youth A and encourage
Youth A to engage in an activity that Youth A likes to
engage in. This safety plan outlines known triggers,
warning signs, coping skills, crisis response.
• Incident Report 201390238 dated 11/30/24 for Youth A.
It is documented that Youth A and another youth
(unidentified in this document), got into an altercation and
Youth A’s hair was pulled. Youth A complained of back pain
following this altercation. It is documented medical
emergency services (EMS) were notified and took Youth A
to the hospital. Youth A was discharged with a
recommendation to use ice on the painful areas, rest, take
ibuprofen, and Youth A was given a Tordayl injection.
• D.A. Blodgett ST. John’s Program Policy – Admission
Policy and Intake Procedure dated 8/2022. It is
documented on this procedure that staff will complete a
clothing inventory checklist (DHHS-3377) and file this
document in the house youth information binder at time of
entry into the program.
• Youth A misc. medical note dated 11/26/24. It is
documented a call was made to the PCP because of back
pain and a rash with Youth A. The RN called back and
scheduled an appointment on 12/4/24 at 3:30 pm.
8

• Youth A misc. medical note dated 11/25/24. It is
documented the RN met with Youth A in the kitchen. Youth
A reported having a rash at times and requested an
appointment with the PCP per Youth A’s mother. The RN
observed bruising on Youth A’s left hand and Youth A
reported no concerns and the hand was getting better.
Youth A reported the bruise was caused by punching over
the weekend (it is not documented what Youth A punched).
• Youth A misc. medical note dated 11/12/24. It is
documented the RN met with Youth A in Youth A’s room for
a medical check-in. Youth A is documented as reporting no
medical concerns at the time.
• Youth A misc. medical note dated 11/19/24. It is
documented the RN met with Youth A in the milieu for a
medical check-in. Youth A asked about a back brace and
the RN reported no concerns about Youth A wearing the
brace. Youth A had no medical concerns at the time.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as evidence by interviews with
staff and written documentation. Evidence supports that the facility
is providing for the medical care of Youth A.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Facility and premises maintenance
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4407
Section (1) A facility and premises shall be maintained in a clean,
Description comfortable, and safe condition. The facility shall be located on
land that is properly drained.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Storing liquid acrylic in the same room that the food is stored in.
Some of the liquid acrylic spilled onto some M&M's
Investigation Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the school on
12/3/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth A
reported having candy in the “overflow” storage area Youth A was
given by Youth F who has left the program. When tasting the
candy, Youth A tasted an acrylic taste because the facility is
storying liquid acrylic in the same room the snacks are stored in.
Youth A also reported Staff 1 tasted the candy and agreed it had
an acrylic taste. This caused Youth A to throw away the candy.
9

Youth A reported the overflow storage room is locked, and the
process is staff will unlock the door and stand in the doorway to
observe the youth get personal items from the room. Each youth
has their own storage container with personal items inside.
Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
12/3/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Administrator
reported knowing nothing about the allegation of Youth A’s candy
tasting like acrylic but did provide a video of Youth A screaming at
staff the day Youth A called Emergency Medical Services to get a
ride to the hospital for Youth A’s back. Youth A was screaming
about the facility trying to kill Youth A with acrylic being placed on
Youth A’s candy.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
12/3/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported
Youth A never said anything to Supervisor about the taste of
acrylic on the candy. She also reported each youth has their own
storage bin in the locked overflow storage closet and youth can
keep nail polish and other items in their own storage bins. The
process involves staff unlocking the overflow pantry for the youth
and staff are to monitor the youth while in the closet. Supervisor
reported nothing hazardous is kept in the overflow closet.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
12/17/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported
remembering the incident when Youth A informed Staff 1 that
Youth A’s candy had a smell of acetone. Staff 1 also reported this
occurred in the middle of November in the overflow pantry. Staff 1
reported the candy was in the general rack in the overflow pantry
and the fingernail items were located across the room in a bucket
on the floor which is their normal location (away from all other
items in the room). Staff 1 also reported smelling the acetone
when walking into the room and observing Youth A taste the
candy. Staff 1 reported telling Youth A not to eat any more after
smelling the acetone. Youth A only said the candy smelled like
acetone but didn’t taste like acetone. Staff 1 also reported having
Youth A throw away the candy in the trash. Staff 1 reported Youth
A made no issue of the situation and just asked for another snack.
Staff 1 also reported not reporting this incident to Supervisor 2
who is Staff 1’s supervisor. Staff 1 described the process of
allowing youth into the overflow pantry as the room is locked all
the time and youth must have staff unlock the door. When youth
are accessing the room, staff are to supervise the youth all the
time the youth is in the room. Snacks (food items) are placed on
the left side of the room and the fingernail products are in a bucket
on the other side of the room. Youth can place their personal
fingernail items in their own storage bins along with other personal
10

items. Staff 1 did not recall if the bag of candy was open when
Youth A picked it up.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
12/17/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Regarding the
overflow pantry, Staff 2 reported the same process for supervision
as other staff interviewed. He also reported sometimes there is the
smell of acetone, but the fingernail items are always kept in the
bucket on the right wall but sometimes a youth will place their
fingernail items in their personal bin.
Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
12/17/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Regarding the
overflow pantry Staff 3 gave the same report as other staff
interviewed about the supervision of youth when entering the
overflow pantry.
Tour Observation:
• The unit Youth A is lodged in was viewed and this includes
the extra storage room that contained the candy and liquid
acrylic items. The storage door was locked, and the candy
was being stored on the left side of the room and the liquid
acrylic items in a bucket on the right side. However, in
Youth A’s personal storage container, there was a small
bottle of liquid acrylic (nail polish removal) and other
personal items. The storage room was clean but needed to
be organized.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as evidence by interviews with
staff and written documentation. Evidence provided through
interviews with youth and staff, along with a walk through does not
support that storage room was not clean and in a safe condition.
Although the facility had different items in the storage room these
items were not close to each other and supervision was provided
when a youth was accessing the room. During this investigation,
the facility shared plans to move the storage room (separating
food from non-food items) to ensure this type of issue is removed.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
11

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
